The prisoner Barrett called on me two or three times in July last; he first said he wanted a harp for a lady: on the 25th he called again and said Mrs. Sutton had been out the evening before and tried a harp - that it made her fingers ache, and she wanted a piano-forte; he asked what it would be a month, I said 26s.; he said he would come the day following and give me an answer - it was to be a cottage piano-forte; he came the next day and said the lady was quite agreeable to the price, and she wished it to be sent that evening, as she had a little party, and wished it particularly; he left me this blue card, with a reference to Mrs. Paul, No. 4, Curzon-street, May-fair, where he said Mrs. Sutton had lived, but she had now taken a house in South-parade, Chelsea - being in ill health I sent my wife there - I do not know whether this was the first time he mentioned the name of Sutton; I sent the harp by my son on the evening of the 26th of July, and two or three days after Barrett called and said Mrs. Sutton was very well pleased with it - I have received no money for the hire - I have seen my piano-forte again for the first time this morning at a pawnbroker's in Houndsditch; I would not have parted with it unless I had received a reference.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. He said he was sent by her? A. Yes, and said he would bring the money for the hire himself.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. What was the price of the best cottage piano-forte you had? A. I do not make expensive ones - there are rosewood ones at seventy guineas; some harps are one hundred and fifty guineas - this piano-forte was worth thirty-six guineas; I did not tell him the price, on my oath - he did not ask me.
Q. Was it not agreed between you, that if the lady chose to buy it, it was thirty-six guineas? A. Never - no such thing was named.

MARY RATHMACHER
. About the 26th of July I went to No. 4, Curzon-street, May-fair - Mrs. Paul was out; I saw a person, who called herself her daughter - I asked her respecting Mrs. Sutton - she said she was a very respectable lady, and had lodged with her mother; I returned to my husband, and told him: on the 26th of August, when the month was expired, I sent my son to receive the hire, and at that same time Barrett came and asked when the month was up; I said it was up, and I had sent my son for the money - he turned out of the shop in great confusion.
Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. Did he not tell you Mrs. Sutton had left the house? A. He did not - nor did he say I should receive the hire in a few days.

MARY PAUL
. I live in Curzon-street, May-fair. A Mrs. Sutton and her mother lodged with me, but I know nothing of the prisoner - I never saw her till I saw her at Bow-street; my daughter had heard me talk of Mrs. Sutton, but did not know her.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. When did Mrs. Sutton live with you? A. About nineteen years ago - it is ten or eleven years since I saw her - I had a letter from her three months ago, dated from Bath; her mother has been dead about fourteen years - I cannot read or write; I received a good many letters from Mrs. Sutton - I have burnt them; I believe if there had been twenty references I should have given them.

COURT. Q. Did you ever know Barrett? A. I believe I have seen him at my house two or three months ago - he called, and asked me to come and see Mrs. Sutton at Queen-elms, and I had a two penny-post letter before that to invite me to see her; I supposed it was the Mrs. Sutton whom I knew - a person had called to say she had returned from Bath.
MR. MILLER. Q. If you had gone to Queen-elms, and seen the prisoner, you would have known she was not the person? A. Yes.

SARAH PAUL
. I am Mrs. Paul's daughter. Mrs.Rathmacher applied to me for Mrs. Sutton's character; I had not seen her, but heard my mother speak of her - I had never seen the prisoner.

ANN ARNOLD
. I know a counting-house in Sherbourne lane - the name of Drummond and Burgh is on the door. I saw the prisoner Sutton there once, and she wrote a letter there - this is it; (looking at the card) - I believe this to be her hand-writing; it corresponds with the letter.
Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. Have you compared it with the letter? A. Yes - my opinion is formed from that comparison, and having seen her write the letter.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Looking at them separately, do you believe the card to be her writing? A. Yes - (card read) "Mrs. Sutton, 12, Queen-elms" - on the reverse side, "Mrs. Paul, Curzon-street, foom twelve o'clock to half-past three."

GEORGE RATHMACHER, JUN.
I took the piano-forte to No. 12, South-parade, Queen-elms, on the 26th of July, and to the best of my belief the woman at the bar is the person who received it; I believe she ran her fingers just over the keys - I afterwards called there for my money, and found Captain Pettingall there; I returned, and told my father - I have since seen the piano-forte at a pawnbroker's in Houndsditch, and am sure it is the same.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How do you know it? A. The fall projects over, and it was never finished - there was only one beading instead of two; our name is on it.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. On your oath, did the female you see here, run her fingers over the keys? A. Yes, and I did the same - she did not play a tune; I stated this at Bow-street - I did not state that she did not touch it; I know two reporters were examined there - I got to the house about four or five o'clock in the afternoon; to the best of my belief the prisoner is the person; I did not see her again till she was at Bow-street - I do not think I had any conversation with her.

Q. Now look at that woman behind you, have you ever expressed a doubt as to which of the two women you saw on that occasion? A. I take that to be the person (the prisoner;) when I was asked about it I could not exactly say which was the woman, because I could not see her face, and when the piano-forte was taken, she kept her back as much as she could towards us; I think the prisoner is the person by her beight - she appears to be the person; I cannot swear which is the woman.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Do you believe the prisoner is the woman? A. Yes - I saw her at Bow-street, and expressed the same belief there.
COURT. Q. When you took the instrument, did you ask for Mrs. Sutton? A. Yes; I went to deliver it to Mrs. Sutton.

THOMAS LOVETT
. I am a porter. I carried the pianoforte to Mrs. Sutton Cook; I understood the name of Cook was on the paper - a female received it, but I did not see her face; I said I had brought a piano-fore from Mr. Rathmacher for Mrs. Sutton Cook, and asked where it was to be placed - she desired it might be brought into the parlour: a table was moved from a recess for it to be placed in - she touched the instrument; I also saw a little child there - the lady gave me something to drink.
Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. Look at that other woman with a child? A. I can swear to the child, but not the woman; I do not believe her to be the woman - I did not see her face.

CAPTAIN PETTINGALL
. I am proprietor of the house at Queen-elms - I let the house to Barrett, that was the name he gave, and referred me to Messrs. Alois and Co., No. 9, Liverpool-street, Broad-street; I went there the following day, and saw a very respectable looking man - he either answered to the name of Alois, or I understood from the representation that he was the person; I said I was referred to him by a man named Barrett, who was about taking a house of me for Mrs. Sutton; he said, "Mrs. Sutton is coming to town, I have received a letter from her from Bath; she is coming to town for her health, and to consult her physician; she stated that a reference would be necessary, and begged me to give it;" I asked if he would guarantee the payment of the rent; he said, "No; I guarantee nobody's debts; but when the quarter or half-quarter is due, if Mrs. Sutton gives you an order on me for the money, I will pay you:" he said she was a very respectable lady, and I think said she was a West Indian; I let the house to Barrett - I told him the reference was perfectly satisfactory, and I would let him have it; I desired him to call on a certain day, which he did, and we finally agreed about it: a paper was signed by my son and Barrett - the signature of Mrs. Sutton was added some days after she was in the house - she came in that evening before I left it; I had lived there before - a woman, who I understood to be her housekeeper, came an hour and a half before - that is the woman who has been pointed out in Caurt.

COURT. Q. Is the prisoner the Mrs. Sutton who took the house? A. Yes, most certainly; I was at the house several times, and once sat an hour with her - she said to me, "Captain Pettingall, I believe my rent is due on the 1st of May, but I shall not receive my money till the 10th, will it make any difference to you?" I said, "Certainly not."

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you get your money on the 10th? A. I am sorry to say not; my house was empty on the 12th of August; I went on the 14th of August, and found Alois and Co. had decamped; I saw Mrs. Sutton sign the agreement, and believe the card to be her writing; my son signed it - as I intended to go abroad I left my son to act for me; the house was let for one hundred and forty guineas per annum.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did Barrett sign it as a witness? A. I suppose so; I did not ask him to sign it.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. Was the house let furnished or not? A. Furnished respectably all over; they did not take it all away - I left a piano-forte there; Barrett said, "Mrs. Sutton will be quite delighted with this, for she is very musical;" my daughter replied, "I don't know that I shall leave it, but I will leave it for two or three months to accommodate the lady;" it is now in my possession - I had it away.
Q. Are you aware that she is the daughter of a west India planter, who left her 40,000l.? A. I knew nothing about it.

THOMAS WOLSTENHOLME
. I am shopman to Mr. Barker, a pawnbroker, of Houndsditch. On the 1st of August Barrett applied to know if I would take in a cottage piano-forte; I knew him before always by the name of Godfrey; and on Saturday morning, between eight and nine o'clock he brought it; I advanced 15l. on it - Rathmacher's name is on it - he has seen it and claimed it; Barrett said it was for a friend of his, and would be removed in a month - but we have it now.

ELIZABETH DOWNEY
. I was servant to Mr. Parkinson, of Greek-street, Soho. I was at Brighton from November to February last - a cousin of mine used to wash for Mrs. Sutton in November; I knew them both there; I came to town in February, Sutton then lived at Chelsea; I remember Barrett being there; I heard Mrs. Sutton say the piano-forte was in pawn for eighteen guineas, but when she could raise the money it should be sent home; this was at my cousin's house in the Borough, the latter end of August; she said she did not pawn it, and did not know where it was, but if she could get eighteen guineas she would take it out and send it home - that she was involved in debt, and she thought she should be taken; I was with her at the Falcon public-house in the Borough, where she was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. She said if she could get eighteen guineas she would take it out, and send it home? A. Yes; I was in Greek-street on the 26th of July - Sutton was there several times on Saturdays, and lived there solely for a time I understand.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When did you see her at Brompton? A. I was there in June, and part of July - I left about the 17th; I was there with her at Mr. Parkinson's about a fortnight - she was at Parkinson's every Saturday - whether she was at Nine-elms, I do not know.
JURY. Q. Was it before she was in trouble, that she said she had the piano in pawn? A. Before.

FRANCIS FAGAN
. I am an officer of Bow-street. I had instructions to apprehend Sutton; I saw her on the 3d of September, and told her she was taken for stealing a piano-forte, the property of Mr. Rathmacher; she made no observations then, but before the Magistrate, she said the piano-forte would be forthcoming, and it might be at Mr. Rathmacher's by that time.

The prisoner SUTTON put in a written defence, protesting her innocence, and stating that circumstances had compelled her to leave the house in South-parade for five weeks, during which time the instrument was sent - that she was not at the house when it was brought, and on her return to the house, on the 3d of August, it was not there; that she was entitled to considerable property by the will of her father, some of which was now in the Accountant-General's hands.

BARRETT, in a long address, stated, that he was an agent for letting and hiring houses, and as such had taken the house for Mrs. Sutton; that he was afterwards arrested upon a forged bill, and Sutton, finding him without a home, had given him an asylum in her house; that he had hired the piano for two months, and intended to redeem and return it, but both himself and Sutton were taken into custody before that time had expired - that it was pawned to prevent its being seized for rent or taxes.
CAPTAIN PETTINGAL. There is not a word of truth in there being any fear that rent or taxes could be seized for.

MARY GRAINGER
. I am a washerwoman. I was at Mrs. Sutton's when the instrument came there - I went after some money she owed me - Mrs. Sutton was not there; the woman who has been pointed out, and a tall thin woman were there, but Mrs. Sutton was not there.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What is your husband? A. A cork-cutter; I never heard the prisoner called any name but Sutton - I have known her twelve months, and I saw Barrett at Walworth about twelve months ago; I never saw him at the house at Chelsea - the child the woman has, is the prisoner's - I did not hear the instrument played.

MR. MILLER. Q. Did you go up stairs into the parlour and kitchen? A. Yes; if she had been there, I must have seen her; this woman gave me a note to take to Greek-street to Mrs. Sutton - she owed me 6s.
COURT. Q. What is that woman? A. The housekeeper - she was up stairs scouring; I went up to speak to her - I was there from three o'clock till about eight.

SAUNDERS -
GUILTY . Aged 38.

BARRETT -
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Transported for Seven Years .
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, OCTOBER 28.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant,

2159.
ALFRED JOHN PEEK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of October , 2 shillings, the monies of
Louis Adolphus Durieu
, his master .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 25.(See Page 935.)

2160.
CAROLINE THOMAS
and
JOHN KIRBY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of September , 1 watch, value 4l.: 1 hat, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Thomas Allan
, from his person .

THOMAS ALLAN. I am a painter . About twelve o'clock at night on the 27th of September, I was going home, and met the female prisoner in Gray's Inn-lane
; I went to her lodging, and slept there all night - in the morning I missed my hat, waistcoat, watch, and money: they were safe in the room the night before, and no other person had been there - I was sober; I know nothing of the man - I do not know that I ever saw him in my life; I dressed myself, went into Gray's Inn-lane, and told the patrol; we afterwards saw the woman going into the house - she was taken and searched, but nothing was found on her.

ELIZABETH BURN
. I keep the house. The prisoner Thomas lodged with me, but I never knew her to bring men there; Kirby lodged in the house that night, and as he went out in the morning I saw him stoop, as if to pick up something.

WILLIAM ALDER
. I am a watchman. The prosecutor gave me charge of Thomas; she was very drunk, and in about an hour afterwards, I saw Kirby with a small hat on his head, which answered the description given by the prosecutor - I took him to the watch-house; he said he had found it, and did not know the party; I said the hat answered the description given by the prosecutor, of a bow tied in a buckle; he said it was his own, and he knew nothing of the woman.

JOHN COOPER
. I am a patrol, and assisted in taking Kirby; I told him a hat was lost, and this answered the description - he said it was his own, and he had bought it - I asked where, but he would not tell me; he told the Magistrate he had picked it up - Thomas said she never saw Kirby, but he lodged in the room over her: this other hat and handkerchief in it, was found in Thomas' room; both the prisoners were drunk, but not the prosecutor.
THOMAS' Defence. I understand that Allan has received 3l. from the young man's brother, in payment for the watch; I never saw him in my life.
KIRBY's Defence. I know nothing of it; I lodged in the house - I came down that morning, and asked for a light: I stooped and picked up this hat in the passage.

THOMAS -
GUILTY. Aged 32. Of stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

KIRBY -
NOT GUILTY .

2161.
WILLIAM ALLENSBY
and
HENRY COOPER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October , 1 watch, value 15s., the goods of
Thomas Field
, from his person .

THOMAS FIELD. I am a Chelsea pensioner . On the 13th of October, I was tipsy - I had been to see my sister in Laystall-street, and left there about five o'clock; I saw my watch safe in my watch-pocket when I came from the house: I think it was about five o'clock, as near as I can guess - I cannot rightly tell; there was a boy to take me home: I got into St. Martin's watch-house that night - while there I missed half a crown, and a sixpence or shilling: I do not rightly know which - I have never seen my watch since; I mentioned to the watch-housekeeper that I had lost it, and he said I blamed him for it - it was a hunting-watch.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. About what time was it you began to miss your watch? A. After I was in the watch-house, about ten o'clock, I believe; I do not know rightly.

WILLIAM WARD
. I was going home with the prosecutor, and in Broad-court the two prisoners came and asked where he was going; I said he was a Chelsea pensioner - Cooper said, "We are going to Pimlico - we will put him into the coach:" they went up Bow-street, and to Hemmings-row, and then another man took hold of him; I followed them all: they went on to the waste ground, and soon afterwards I saw the prosecutor on the ground, and the third man was with him - I went up to him, and saw his watch was gone; I said if I knew where there was an officer I would have the man taken up - I called out Stop thief! and the third man, said,"There go the two men who have robbed him," and he took to his heels and ran away; King came up - I said, "This man has been robbed of his watch;" I know it was safe before, for I felt it - King and I took him to the watch-house.

Cross-examined. Q. When did the third man come up? A. Just before they got to Hemmings-row; the prisoners were gone when I found him on the ground; I cannot say at what time he lost his watch: when the third man ran away the prisoners were in Pall Mall east - I was in the middle of the waste ground; I wanted to get home, and thought they were gentlemen - I followed, to see if they would put him into a coach.

JAMES KING
. I live in Long-court, Leicester-square. On the night of the 13th of October, between half-past six and seven o'clock, I saw the two prisoners in Bow-street, together; they stood there a few minutes - two or three more persons were with them; I then saw Cooper and Ward turn into Long-acre, with Allensby and two more men; they all went down St. Martin's-lane, and then down Hemmings-row
- Ward then left them, and Allensby took hold of his arm; they turned down towards the mews - the other two were a little way behind - they took him to about the middle of the waste ground - I saw the prosecutor down on the ground, and the prisoners one on each side of them; I did not see what they did - the other two men did not follow then, but remained at a distance; Ward was at a distance like me - he was following, to see what they did; we were in front of the United Club-house - Cooper went away, up the Strand, but Allensby brought the prosecutor part of the way out, then let him fall, and ran off up the Strand - Ward and I got up to the prosecutor about the same time; Ward felt, and said he had lost his watch - I took him to the watch-hosue; an officer was sent with me, but we could not see the prisoners that night; I then went to the Theatre, and saw Allensby coming down the gallery-stairs, with different coloured trousers on - I turned to look for an officer, but could see none, and on turning back he was gone; I saw Cooper next morning, at the corner of Catherine-street - I stopped some time, and then saw Allensby come from behind the English Opera-house; they went on up Drury-lane, were joined by another man, went into a public-house, and I had them apprehended.

Cross-examined. Q. Then you never lost sight of them from Broad-court till they ran away? A. No; nobody remained with him after Allensby left him - we both got up to him together; Allensby was then running - the prosecutor was very drunk. Allensby had once met me at an anction-room in the Poultry; he struck me, and called me an informer, because I had appeared against Cooper. his comrade.

HANNAH HUMPHRIES
. I live in the Strand. I saw Allensby come home that evening; he took off a pair of light trousers, and put on dark ones.
Cross-examined. Q. What coat had he? A. A. dark one.

FRANCIS FAGAN
. I apprehended the prisoners; the property has never been found - they denied the charge: I found 2s. 6d. on Allensby.

ALLENSBY put in a written Defence, denying that he had been with the prosecutor, but that the present charge arose from a conspiracy on the part of King, for having assaulted him, and the Bow-street officer, on account of his having exposed their conduct at the Theatres. before the Police Committee.

WILLIAM WARD
. There are gas-lights round the place - I think the man who left the prosecutor last was taller than Allensby.

ALLENSBY -
GUILTY . Aged 28.

COOPER -
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2162.
ELIZA YATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 shawl, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Barker
, from the person of
Mary Barker
.
THOMAS BARKER. I am the father of Mary Barker. - On the 14th of August she went out with the child, who had a shawl on; she returned about three o'clock, without the shawl.

MARY BARKER. I am nine years old. I was coming from my grandmother's, in Whitecross-street; I met a lady, and I met the prisoner at the corner of Banner-street - she asked if I knew the lady, and asked where I was going - I said, home to Old-street: she said, "Don't go up Whitecross-street - there is a mad horse tumbled down;" she took me up Banner-street, and wanted me to go to the field, then took me to the mad-house - she took me up Brick-lane, and said my mother wanted the shawl, but I would not let her have it till I got opposite our door; she then took it, ran over, and pretended to give it to my sister; I went in soon after, and found my mother had not sent for it.

JOHN FORSYTH
. I am a surgeon. On the 9th of October I met Mary Barker, who pointed the prisoner out, with three other girls; she said she was certain she was the girl who took her shawl - I asked the prisoner to go with me to the child's father; she said she had no objection, but went reluctantly.
MARY BARKER re-examined. I know her by her talk, and her face - I was about an hour and a half with her.
NOT GUILTY .

2163.
ROBERT ARCHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of September , at St. James, Clerkenwell
, 1 coat, value 5l.: 1 pelisse, value 3l.; and 1 umbrella, value 8s., the property of
John Plumb
, in his dwelling-house; and that the said Robert Archer before the said felony was committed, that is to say, at the Delivery of the King's Gaol of Newgate holden for the county of Middlesex, at Justice Hall, in the Old Bailey, on the 3d of June, in the fifth year of the reign of our Lord the King, was convicted of Felony .

LOUISA PLUMB
. I am the wife of John Plumb; we live at No. 27, Chapel-street
, in the parish of St. James, Clerkenwell - my husband is a jeweller . On the 24th of September, there was a knock at the door; I went, and saw the prisoner there - he had the appearance of a gentleman; he gave a note into my hand, which was not sealed; I asked who he brought it from - he said from Mr. Oxley, or some such name; I said "I don't think this note is for me" - he said "If you open it you will see;" I took it up stairs, but did not stop hardly a minute - I came down again, and missed a travelling pelisse, a box-coat, and an umbrella, from the passage - the door was wide open, and the prisoner gone; the value of the articles was at least 9l. - one of them was quite new and had not been worn above once or twice in the chaise; I was much alarmed - I went out, and a woman asked me if I had lost any thing, and I told her - I have never got them again.

Prisoner. Q. What time was it? A. Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening - it was quite a moon-light night; I had not a light; I stated at the office that the person had light trousers, and a blue coat buttoned quite close.

COURT. Q. Are you sure he is the man? A. Yes - I am quite positive I saw him at the door - I stood talking with him I suppose about five minutes, I had no light, but it was quite light - I could see to read at the door; it was a beautiful night - the 24th of September.

Q. What did the woman say to you? A. She asked if I had lost a coat; I said I had two; I saw her at Hatton-garden, but she is not here; her name is Shanks - she is the prisoner's mother-in-law, as she stated; this is the note the prisoner brought.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I took the prisoner in charge.(Note read.)
Bermuda, 1828.

SISTER - I now take an opportunity of writing - lines to you, hoping they will - you in good health as they leave - at present. I have been very ill for - time, and have been in the Navy-hospital for five weeks, but am now - recovered, and expect to arrive at - mouth in a little time, as we are prep - to put to sea. I will let you know - I arrive there, as I shall want some help - my trunks home as they are loaded - xes, specimens of rock, and all sorts of - dsome shells; so no more at present.
I remain your affectionate brother,

SAMUEL OXLEY
.
Prisoner's Defence. I positively deny the charge.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 28. (See page 940.)

2164.
THOMAS EVANS
and
JAMES DEANE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
John Howard
.

JOHN BELSHAM
. I am foreman to Mr. John Howard, a shoemaker , St. Martin's-court
. On the 16th of September, the prisoner Evans was brought in with a pair of shoes - I took them from him; I have seen him about once or twice, but I did not see Deane that morning.

WILLIAM BALCH
. I am a hatter, and live in St. Martin's-court. On the 16th of September, between ten and eleven o'clockin the morning, I saw Deane take the shoes from Mr. Howard's door, and give them to Evans - I had frequently seen them lurking about the shop.

JOHN GROOM
. I am an officer. I took Deane about four hours after the other; I knew they were in the habit of going about together.(Property produced and sworn to.)

EVANS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

DEANE -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2165.
REUBEN HALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of October
, 3lbs. weight of garden seeds, value 12l., the goods of the Horticultural Society of London, his masters
; and
GEORGE FREDERICK WOOD
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same .

Both the prisoners
pleaded GUILTY ; And received good Characters.
Confined Three Months .

2166.
JAMES DOYLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 basket, value 1s.; 1 counterpane, value 17s.; 2 towels, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 9d.; and 1 apron, value 9d. , the goods of
Martha Sartin
.

MARTHA SARTIN. I am a widow . On the 16th of October, I left these articles at the door of my house, in a basket - I think at twelve o'clock in the evening; the next morning, at a quarter-past six, I heard a voice, saying"There is a thief in the yard;" I opened my window, butthere was no one there - but the basket had been moved to the upper end of the yard.

WILLIAM STAR
. On the 16th of October, I was getting up at six o'clock in the morning; I saw the prisoner take the basket of linen from one end of the yard to the other; he had got a ladder, and got over the wall; I went down stairs into the street, expecting to see him - instead of coming into the street, he went down a mews; I am sure I saw him taking the basket towards the ladder.

JOHN BENSTEAD
. On the 16th of October, I saw the prisoner about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning; he was just getting over the wall, but had nothing in his hand; I dressed myself, and searched for him, but could not find him; in about a quarter of an hour, I searched for him again, and saw him jump from a wall into an empty house; I looked about, and found him in an archway, concealed under some straw; he said he came there to sleep; I told him he must go with me; I sent for the officer - he said If I would let him go, he would never do so any more.
Prisoner's Defence. I told him I had slept there, and if he would let me go I would never go there any more.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

2167.
THOMAS CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of September , 1 half-crown, value 2s.; 1 sixpence. and 10d. in copper coin, the monies of
Edmund Ryan
, from his person .

EDMUND RYAN. On the 30th of September, about five o'clock in the morning; I was in a public-house, dozing - I had a half-crown, two shillings, a sixpence, and 10d., in copper, and four duplicates, which were in my fob-pocket; I had pawned a coat the day before for 6s.; I pulled off my dress at night, but that morning I was going to my work - while I sat on the bench, the prisoner came and sat next to me, and took my money from my pocket; the watchman came to the house, and took him.

Prisoner. Q. Was not I drinking with you that morning, and you gave me the duplicates to take care of, and at the watch-house you and the watchman both agreed to let me go for half a crown? A. No - we were not drinking - I never saw him before; I did not give him the duplicates, nor offer to let him go for half a crown.

STEPHEN RENEN
. I am a watchman. I went to the public-house; I heard a noise of loud talking as I was going by; I looked in, and saw Ryan sitting on the bench in the tap-room asleep; the prisoner was on his right-hand with his right-hand in his waistcoat pocket; he then went to his left-hand pocket, and took something out, but I could not tell what, and he put it into his own waistcoat pocket - I stood with my back against the counter, and watched him - when he had got what he thought proper to take, I called my partner, and we took the prisoner up to Ryan, awoke him up, and asked if he had lost any thing, he put his hand into his pocket, and said he had lost half a crown, some silver, and, copper; we took the prisoner to the watch-house, and found half a crown, two shillings, a sixpence, and 10d., and four duplicates; the prosecutor was sober.
Prisoner. Q. Is not my statement true about his offering to let me go for half a crown? A. I know nothing of that.

DANIEL HANKS
. I am a watchman. I assisted in taking the prisoner - we found the half-crown, two shillings, a sixpence, 10d. in copper, and this knife open in his pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I was drinking with him; the Magistrate reprimanded the watchman for agreeing to let me go for 2s. 6d.; the prosecutor came home last night, and said he should speak the truth, and that he was drinking with me.
EDMUND RYAN. I had been out to the City-road the night before with a friend; the prisoner was not in the house when I went to sleep; when I awoke, he said I was his friend.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined One Year .

2168.
JAMES COHEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 shawl, value 9s. , the goods of
John Reed
.

HANNAH REED
. I am the wife of John Reed. On the 10th of October I saw the prisoner in a blacksmith's shop, where our poney was being shoed; I sent my daughter there; she had the shawl on, and I saw the prisoner with it in his hand in the shop - my daughter came home without it; she and my husband went afterwards for it.

MARY REED
. I am the daughter of Hannah Reed. I had the shawl in the shop about seven o'clock that evening - I laid it down while I put some straw down; I left it there, as I forgot it, and on going back in half an hour - it was gone.

EDWARD SIMPSON
. I am a last-maker. On the 10th of October, I saw Mary Reed about half-past eight o'clock, and about half-past nine I saw the prisoner at the corner of Warwick-place, and asked what he had done with she with the woman's shawl? he said "I sold it for 2s., on Saffron-hill;" and next morning he told me he had bought a cup with one shilling of the money; he sometimes blows the bellows at the smiths'.

THOMAS ELLIOTT
. I work at the blacksmith's. The prisoner came there on the 11th of October - master asked if he had seen the shawl in the shop; he said No; master said he would give him 3s. to fetch it back; he said he knew nothing about it; nobody but him had been in the shop while I was there, but I went out.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I took the prisoner in charge last Friday week; I searched him, but could find nothing - he had a new cap on; I asked where he got it; he said Johnson, the farrier, gave him 1s., and he brought it; he was let go, but taken again afterwards.
Prisoner's Defence. If she saw me with it, why did not she stop me.
NOT GUILTY .

2169.
MARY CLANCEY
and
SUSANNAH TURBITT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of September , 3 gowns, value 30s.; 1 jacket, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s. 6d.; 3 pair of stockings, value 3s.; 2 aprons, value 1s.,; 2 pair of gloves, value 1s.; 1 petticoat, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns; 1 half-sovereign, and 5s. , the property of
Barbara Mitchell
.

BARBARA MITCHELL. I am a widow . On the 23d of September, I was in Bainbridge-street, St. Giles', and met the prisoner; I had a large band-box, containing all thisproperty; I asked Turbitt if she could recommend me to part of a bed for the night, as it was then half-past ten o'clock; she said she had a bed, and if I would take a part of it, I was very welcome; I said I did not wish to have it without making her satisfaction; we went to a room in Bainbridge-street
- the other prisoner was there; in about an hour I went to bed with Turbitt - I do not know where Clancey was; in the morning I was awoke by the opening of a window about half-past four o'clock; I got up, and heard footsteps running down stairs - there was no one in the room, but the room-door slammed too very quick; all my things were gone but the box - I heard something fall from the window - I looked, but could see nothing; I called the watchman but he did not come for some time; I have never got any of my property since.

WILLIAM BALL
. I am an officer. I took the prisoners and charged them with the robbery, but they denied it.
TURBITT's Defence. I never saw the woman till I was at Bow-street.
CLANCEY'S Defence. I was taken that day, but I had never seen the woman.
WILLIAM BALL. Clancey said before the Magistrate that she slept in the room.

CLANCEY -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

TURBITT -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2170.
ABRAHAM BATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October , 2 fur tippets, value 3l. , the goods of
Jacob Harris
.

LEVY JACOBS
. On the 14th of October the prisoner brought two fur tippets to my shop for sale; I asked how he came by them - he said he had them to sell, and that he, manufactured them; I asked where he lived - he said in White Horse-court, Cow-cross; I took the tippets, and went to the place - he kept dodging me about for some time; at last we went to the house, and saw two or three women; I asked if he lived there - they said Yes; I asked his trade - they said he was a working smith, and they did not know of his having the tippets; they were astonished on seeing them - he was going to snatch at them, and he did get them from me; people came round, and said I wanted to make a property of him - he then went away into Cow-cross; a friend of mine came up - we went after him, and found him in Cow-cross with the tippets; I took them from him - he followed me through Sharp's-alley to West-street, and there made a stop; a mob gathered - an officer came up, and took him.

JACOB HARRIS I keep a furrier's shop in Peter-street
. The officer gave me these tippets at Hatton-gardon - they are mine, and were safe about a quarter-past one o'clock on the 14th of October; I was out of the shop about ten minutes, and then missed them.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought them of a decent young woman in the street, and wanted to sell them to pay my rent; I asked 1l. for them - Jacobs offered 9s., and said if I would not take that he would take me into custody.
LEVY JACOBS. He asked no price - he was beastly drunk.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Transported for Seven Years .

2171.
JOHN GRIFFIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of September , 1 sovereign , the money of
Ann Mannox
.

ANN MANNOX. I am single - I was in the service of Mr. Deacon, of St. John's-street-road
. The prisoner was employed there half a day on the 24th of September - I took the breakfast up stairs about a quarter to nine o'clock, and stopped to make a bed, leaving him in the back kitchen; I came down in a quarter of an hour, and he was gone - I missed a sovereign in about two hours from a box in the back kitchen; it was locked, but the key was in another box - my clothes, and about 3l. 10s. in silver were on the box; I saw him next morning in custody - his mother asked how he came to take my sovereign - he said he was very sorry, and that he had changed it of a man at the canal, who he bought some fishing things of.

CHARLES HERDSFIELD
. On the 24th of September I saw the prisoner in Mr. Rhodes' brick-field, with a fishing-rod, a can and bag - he said, "See what I have found;" I said, "Don't tell stories, the lady has been to your mother, and says you have stolen it" - he then said he had found the sovereign, and told me to tell nobody.

SAMUEL BRIDGES
. I found 5s. 6d. in the prisoner's pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Whipped and Discharged .

2172.
JOHN NELSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 hat, value 7s. , the goods of
William Gravenor
.

WILLIAM GRAVENOR. I am a hatter , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. On the 5th of September I saw the prisoner take a hat from a rail outside my shop - I took him with it; he said he was in distress.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY
. Aged 40.
Judgment Respited.

2173.
JOHN MASTERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October , 2 1/2 lbs. weight of cauliflower-seed, value 30s. , the goods of
William Adamson
.

JOHN ADAMSON
. I am the son of William Adamson, a gardener of Newington
. On the 20th of October, in consequence of information, I got Brown, the officer, and went to the prisoner, who was at work in our ground; we asked to see his jacket - the officer took it off the ground, and found a bundle of cauliflower-seed; he begged forgiveness, and said he would not do the like any more - it was worth about 30s.; he had 16s. a-week.

JOHN SMITH
. I am a labourer to Mr. Adamson; I saw the prisoner go into the barn where this seed is kept - I did not see him come out; he had no business there - I saw him in about ten minutes with a parcel in his hand; I gave information.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not beckon me to the barn? A. No.

JOHN MARSHALL
. I saw the prisoner come out of the barn, but saw nothing in his hand; I had put this seed in a sack there.

ROBERT BROWN
. I am an officer. I went up to the prisoner, and asked to see his jacket; he shewed it to me - I took it up, and this fell out of it; he begged forgiveness, and said he did not know that he had so much, or he should have put three parts of it back.
Prisoner's Defence. It is done merely to throw me out of employ, as the men had whispered that I should not be there long.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Confined Four Months .

2174.
THOMAS MYERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 1 coat, value 5s , the goods of
Patrick Sullivan
.

JAMES SULLIVAN
. I am the son of Patrick Sullivan - he lives in Mary-le-bone
. On the morning of the 15th of October, about half-past seven o'clock, I hung this coat over a broken pane of glass in the window - my mother said it was gone; I got up, and missed it - I went out and saw the prisoner and another boy doubling it up; they were a few yards off - I cried Stop thief! and went up to them; they ran different ways - the prisoner was stopped without my losing sight of him; they dropped the coat - my mother picked it up.
Prisoner. The other boy dropped it. Witness. Both had hold of it - I cannot say which dropped it.

HUMPHREY ROBERTS
. I saw the prisoner running - he was stopped, and said no one could prove that he had the coat, and we could only give him a night's lodging.
Prisoner's Defence. I ran; a boy came up and said, "I'll stop you, you young rascal;" I turned round and said, "Why do you call Stop thief! after me" - they then gave charge of me.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

2175.
ELIZABETH LESLIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October , 24 yards of moreen, value 20s. , the goods of
Charles John Brooks
.

WILLIAM STANLEY
. I am in the service of Mr. Charles John Brooks, a draper , who lives in Oxford-street
. On the 17th of October, I heard a rustling at the door; I looked and saw the prisoner with a piece of moreen under her arm, trying to conceal it - it had been against the door, and secured by some gros de Naples upon it, and pinned; she went half-way across the road, and I took her with it, walking slowly - I brought her back.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and produce the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated, and throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

2100.
RICHARD LEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s.; 2 waistcoats, value 7s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 4s., and 1 pair of boots, value 8s. , the goods of
John Williams
.

JOHN WILLIAMS. On the 10th of October, I went into the City of Hereford public-house
, about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon, and had these things in a bundle, on the table; I saw the prisoner there - some of the men said my bundle was gone while I went across the room to speak to another man.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say to me, "Take care of this till to-morrow? A. No; I had been drinking.

SAMUEL SEDDONS
. I am a watchman. I stopped the prisoner about half-past twelve o'clock at night, on the 10th, in Bull's Head-court, Peter-street, with a bundle under his arm, containing all these articles; I asked whose they were - he said they belonged to Mr. Gillott, who had gone to St. Alban's fair to perform for Richardson; he appeared to have been drinking.

THOMAS COLLIER
. I was in the tap-room, about half-past six o'clock; I saw Williams, and the prisoner drinking at the same table - I saw the prisoner take the bundle, and walk out with it, while Williams was talking to a person - I thought he knew him, but found he did not; I told the prosecutor.

THOMAS HOWARD
, I was in the tap-room, and saw the prosecutor come in with a bundle, he said he wanted somebody to carry it to Lambeth - they all sat drinking and singing together for half an hour; I saw the prisoner take up the bundle, and thought he was going to the bar with it- I do not know where he went.

JOHN CRAIGHEAD
. I am a constable. The prisoner and property were brought to the watch-house; he said they belonged to Gillott.
Prisoner's Defence. I was much intoxicated; the prosecutor gave it me to take care of.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .

2178.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 2 table-cloths, value 8s.; 1 pair of salt-holders, value 5s., and 6 glass castors, value 9s. , the goods of
George Catlin
.

SEBIA CATLIN
. I am the wife of George Catlin, who keeps an eating-house in Aylesbury-street, Clerkenwell
. On the 16th of October the prisoner came there for his dinner; he paid 7d. for it, and then went out - I thought all was not right; my husband went and missed the property off the table; he fetched the prisoner back with it; he produced it from his person.

CHARLES FREEMAN
. I was at Mr. Catlin's on the 16th; I saw the prisoner come to the house and go up stairs; I afterwards saw the prosecutor bring him back - he pulled the table-cloth from his hat, and the other things from his pocket.

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEVENS
. I am an officer. I received him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

2178.
WILLIAM TIDMARSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of October , 1 hearth-rug, value 1l. , the goods of
John Blinkin
.

JOHN BLINKIN. I live at Islington
. I lost this rug on the 11th of October.

SARAH WEBB
. I am servant to Mr. Blinkin; I hung this rug over the wall about half-past ten o'clock in the morning, and missed it in half an hour; I know nothing of the prisoner.

GEORGE UPWARD
. I met the prisoner in Islingtonfields on the 11th of October, with this rug tucked in his blue apron - I followed him across one field, then stoppedand asked where he was going - he would give no answer; I asked where he got it - he said he found it; I asked where? he took me back and shewed me a place which he had passed while I was following him - I then seized him.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

2179.
BENJAMIN THORNEYGOLD
and
CHARLOTTE MONK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 2 sheets, value 5s.; 2 pillow cases, value 1s., and 1 counterpane, value 6s. , the goods of
William Welch
.

CAROLINE WELCH
. I am the wife of William Welch, a shoemaker , of Laystall-street
. The prisoners took a furnished room at our house on the 11th of October; they passed as man and wife - these things were let with the room; they were out on the 17th - I got into their room, and missed these articles; they returned at night, and I gave them in charge; before the constable came the man ran away - I called out Stop thief! and he was brought back.
WILLIAM WELCH. I charged the prisoners with stealing my property; the woman acknowledged it, and gave me three duplicates; I asked where the rest of the property was; she would not own to that.

DANIEL PARKER
. I stopped the man who was running.

JOHN ADAMAN
. The female prisoner pawned this sheet and pillow-case with me on the 16th of October.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD
. I have a counterpane pawned on the 16th of October.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am a constable, and took the prisoners in charge; the man said if they would forgive him he would return the things next morning - and he told the Magistrate it was done through distress.
The prisoners pleaded distress.

THORNEYGOLD -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Six Months .

MONK -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined One Month .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2180.
LOUISA HUGALL
was indicted for
embezzlement .

ANN DAVIS
. I am the wife of
William Davis
, a journeyman baker , who lives in the City-road. I employed the prisoner as my servant , to take home my washing, and paid her weekly; she lived in the house - if any one paid her she was to receive it, and account to me directly she came home; she had been about four weeks with me - I washed for Gerald, who always paid when the linen went home.

SARAH GERALD
. On the 13th of September I received some things from Mrs. Davis by the prisoner - I paid her 2s.; she brought a bill, but I did not have it receipted.

ANN DAVIS. When she returned on the 13th she said Mrs. Gerald had no change - I found it out three days after, when I found several things put aways - she absconded; she did not return after Wednesday evening, the 13th.

JAMES GLIBBERY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - her father is a very respectable man, and a tallow-chandler.

GUILTY
. Aged 16.
Judgement Respited.

2281.
WILLIAM BILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of October , 4 pair of stockings, value 20s.; 1 pair of half stockings, value 1s., and 2 shillings , the property of
John Austen
, his master.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN AUSTEN. I am a linen-draper , and live in Fair-street, Manchester-square
. The prisoner was in my employ from the 2d or 3d of September - he was taken up on the 3d of October; his salary was 40l. and he lived in the house - I never gave him leave to take any of my goods; in consequence of suspicion I marked 9s. in shillings and sixpences, and delivered them to Mrs. Seaward.

MARY SEAWARD
. On the 2d of October I received some marked money from Mr. Austen, and delivered the same money to Prince.

ELIZABETH PRINCE
. I received 9s. in shillings and sixpences from Mrs. Seaward on the 2d of October; I was not aware that it was marked; I was sent for nine yards of linen, at 1s. a yard - the prisoner served me; I paid him the same money as I received from Mrs. Seward about seven o'clock.

MR. AUSTEN. I was not at home when this took place; I waited at the witness' house, and went home immediately; I then sent the prisoner out to get sovereigns for silver which I took out of my cash-box; when he was gone I looked into the till and found 7s. of the marked money, and about 2s. or 3s. of other money, or possibly not that; I sent for an officer on the prisoner's return, and said in his presence that I wished to have him searched, and wished to know whether he had any silver in his pocket like this, shewing a private mark on a shilling; 2s. of the marked money was found on him; his box was searched in his presence - he said it was his; two pairs of white stockings, two pairs of half-stockings, and one pair of silk stockings, were found, which I believe to be mine; they had all been worn except the half-hose - the three pair of stockings had S, the maker's mark on them, but no mark of my own; he had one pair on which I found the same mark on; I said if he came down stairs I thought I should be able to produce papers of the same.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Had you a lad named Nash in your service? A. Yes; I do not know of the prisoner lending him 2s.; the prisoner told the Magistrate, if my apprentice was there he could state that he had lent him 2s.; I said he should come, and fetched him; all manufacturers mark their stockings; I missed one pair out of one paper.

HENRY STOWELL
. I am an officer. I have the stockings and the two shillings.
The Prisoner's Counsel called -

FREDERICK NASH
. I am apprentice to Mr. Austen. The prisoner was in his service - he lent me two shillings on Mr. Austen's account, not for myself, and it was understood he was to pay himself; he never told me he had taken it out of the till.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When did he lend it? A. About a fortnight or three weeks before; he never asked me nor Mr. Austen for it.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Did he never mention to you that he had taken the two shillings? A. No - he said the same morning before breakfast that the till owed him 2s.
HENRY STOWELL re-examined. Q. Before I searchedhim, he said he had 2s. or 3s. which he had had some days; I found 2s. 6d. on him.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you remember his desiring the boy to be fetched before the Magistrate? A. Yes; Mr. Austen said he should come; the prisoner said the till owed him 2s., and he had paid himself.
NOT GUILTY .

2182.
DOROTHY CLAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 3s; 1 purse, value 1d.; 1 sovereign, and 3s. 6d. the property of
James Barber
, from his person .

JAMES BARBER. I am a cabinet-maker , and live at Hammersmith. On the 20th of October, between twelve and one o'clock at night, I met the prisoner at Hyde-park corner
, she asked me to walk with her; I objected; she then put her arm round me, and forced her hand into my trousers - I did not miss any thing; I was not more than three minutes with her; I had a parcel in each hand and one under my arm - a friend came up and wished to pull me away; she called a watchman to take him for wanting me to go, and when the watchman came up he gave charge of her; he told me to look to my pockets - I then found she had my handkerchief under her shawl; I drew it out; my purse was found on the parcel but it contained no money; I had missed a sovereign and 3s. from my trousers pocket, which have not been found - it was all safe five minutes before; my coat and pocket were buttoned.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where do you live? A. At Hammersmith; I do not know the name of my friend who came up - I had been in his company two or three times; the Magistrate adjourned the case for me to produce him, but I could not find him; I have met him at the Crown public-house; I had no gilt coins about me; I did not ask her to take me home - I did not feel her hand in my pockets; the money was in my trousers, and the handkerchief and purse in my coat pocket; I had been drinking, but nothing to make me elevated; I had spent the evening at Mr. Walker's.
COURT. Q. How long were you with her? A. Not above three minutes; I thought I could get away without the watchman.

JAMES QUICK
. I am a watchman. I was called about a quarter to one o'clock - I was in Grosvenor-place; the prisoner, prosecutor, and another person were talking - the other man told me to part them; the prosecutor and his friend then went and had a few words together: the prosecutor then came back and said, "You have robbed me of a sovereign, 3s. 6d., and a handkerchief;" I saw the handkerchief hanging under her arm; he took it from her, and as he stooped to take up a parcel he found a purse on it; I found no sovereign on her.

Cross-examined. Q. Till this private whispering there was no charge against her? A. No; the prosecutor was sober - I searched but could find no sovereign; a gilt farthing fell down on going to the watch-house.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me this pocket-piece for a shilling.
NOT GUILTY .

2183.
MARGARET LYONS
and
SARAH BROWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October , 1 apron, value 2d.; a pair of spectacles, value 5s.; 4 yards of linen, 8s.; 1 shawl, value 8s; 2 handkerchiefs, value 8s., 3 sovereigns, and 1 crown, the property of
Thomas Guilliam
, from his person .

THOMAS GUILLIAM. I am a labourer , and live at Deptford, and work on the grounds. On the 14th of October, about seven or eight o'clock at night, I was going to Deptford, and met the prisoners in Broad-street, Westminster; they got hold of my arms, and said they would not let me go till I treated them with a glass of gin; I went to two different houses, and gave them a glass at each - they then would not let me go, but led me to a little room, threw me on a bed, and continued their talking, and wanted more liquor; I got drowsy - I did not go to sleep; I felt their hands rubbing about me; I had all these articles in a bundle on the bed, and the sovereign in a little fob in my waistcoat - they got that out; I felt them searching me; I fell asleep, and then they got hold of me, and threw me out of doors - I awoke - I was in liquor; I called for my hat, and presently they threw my hat and purse out - I did not move from the door till the watchman came in the morning, at six o'clock - another man had told him of it; he called out, but they would not open the door; he sent me for another watchman - they then got in, and searched the house; they found an old apron, which I had bound three times round my waist - I have found nothing else; nobody but the prisoners were in the house - they were in the same bed as they dragged me into; I was asleep when they took the bundle - I had not undressed.

DAVID PHILLIPS
. I am a watchman. The watch-house is in Perkins'-rents, Old Pye-street; a man came and told me a poor working man had been robbed; I went down to the house, which I had known of old, and saw the prosecutor; I knocked at the door, but could get no answer - I then sent for the next watchman, who came- I then knocked again, and said if they did not open it I would break in; a voice said "Wait a bit;" I then heard a running to and fro in the passage - we went into the house, and found nothing; the other watchman found this apron in the yard; it is very unusual for the door to be shut at all, but that night it was well bolted; there are some cow-houses at the back of the yard.

JOHN DEMPSEY
. I am a watchman. I found the apron on a shed in the back yard.

LYON'S Defence. This is not the woman who was with me - it was another, much more slender than me; he called me over to him, and asked me to treat him - he went to my door, and we parted; as to the apron, there is but one yard to the three houses.
BROWN'S Defence. I was in bed before eleven o'clock that night, and was not with this girl; it was a slender young woman who goes by the name of Scotch Bet - her name is Eliza Parker.
THOMAS GUILLIAM. When I got to the house, there was a woman in bed; the prisoners are the people who pulled me into the house - they were found in bed the next morning, and undressed.

LYONS -
GUILTY - Aged 22.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .

2184.
ANN MARY CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 3 spoons, value 7s.; 3 table cloths, value 14s., and 1 towel, value 6d. , the goods of
William Hicks
.
MR. PRENDERGAST conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM HICKS. I live in Old-street
; the prisoner was my nurse . I missed property, and gave direction to Meadows; and on the 15th of October, the prisoner was apprehended at my house; I charged her with stealing spoons, table cloths, and a towel; she said she had not got the duplicates, but had lent them, or made away with them, but she could shew where the things were pawned; she took us to Burgess, who produced a table cloth, and towel; from there she took us to Mr. Smith's, where we found three spoons and a table cloth. I am independent - I took her from the workhouse.

GEORGE MEADOWS
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner, went to the pawnbroker's, and found the property.

SIDNEY SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. Meadows and the prosecutor came to my house, and I produced the spoons and table cloth.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received an excellent character.

GUILTY
. Aged 36.
Recommended to Mercy. - Judgment Respited.

2185.
JOSEPH HILLIER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of September , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 pair of boots, value 12s.; 9 handkerchiefs, value 20., and 2 shirts, value 5s. , the goods of
James Kemp
.

JAMES KEMP. I am coachman to Mr. Stevens, of Brighton. I lost the articles stated in the indictment from Regency-square, Brighton
, at the back of the mews, on the morning of the 28th of September, or the night before - some were in the stable, and part in my bed-room; I saw the prisoner in the room that morning - he had been working in the stables, and was going to assist me - he left that morning, about five o'clock, and about ten I missed my property; I could not find him.

- HART. I am an officer of Upper Tooting. I apprehended the prisoner in Wardour-street; I had come to town with Pleasant. I found part of the property at his lodging, No. 32, Wardour-street; his wife was in the room - we were watching for him there from half-past eleven to half-past one o'clock, and then saw him coming up the street; Pleasant said, "This is him;" he turned down a passage - I ran, and collared him; he said, "Is that you, Pleasant?' I found at his lodging three white handkerchiefs and other things.

JOHN VIRGO BUCKLAND
. I am a constable of St. James'. I assisted in taking the prisoner, and on his person found this handkerchief and watch.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

2186.
JOSEPH HILLIER
was again indicted for
staling, on the 26th of September , 1 watch, value 30s.; 2 waistcoats, value 10s.; 1 shirt, value 5s.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 neckcloth, value 1s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; and 1 pair of boots, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Pleasant
.

ROBERT PLEASANT. I am coachman to a gentleman at Brighton
. I lost these articles from my room at the mews the same morning; the prisoner assisted now and then at the stable; I came to town with the constable, and went to Wardour-street, where I found my property - he had my boots on; a watch and two handkerchiefs were found.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He left them in my room.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years, from the expiration of his former sentence .

2187.
THOMAS BAYLIS
was indicted for
embezzlement .

SAMUEL WESTCOTT TILKE
. I live in High-street, Mary-le-bone
, and am a baker . The prisoner was my apprentice , and employed to receive money; George Parker owed me 3s. 9d.
GEORGE PARKER. I paid the prisoner 3s. 9d. on the 7th of October , on Mr. Tilke's account.
MR. TILKE. He paid me 11d. on this account, on the 7th of October; here is the entry in his own writing - he settles with me every evening; he was taken on another charge.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it not for spoiling rolls that you took him? A. Yes, on the 7th of October, in the evening; but he had made up his book before he went; if there was any errors we correct them on Sunday - he once summoned me to the office: the Magistrate dismissed the charge, and said it was a mercy to horsewhip him, for kicking me; I said if he went on in that way he would soon be there again - he has been two years with me.
Prisoner's Defence. The very evening I made this mistake I pointed out an error of five loaves.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

2188.
HENRY EDWARDS
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

CATHERINE EDWARDS
. I am the wife of
Henry Edwards
, who left me about eleven years ago; I have not heard of him for eight years. The prisoner is my eldest son; I am a baker - he managed my business for some years, and conducted himself well till lately. On the 13th of October Biggs owed me 13l.

MARGARET BIGGS
. I keep a chandler's-shop, and deal with the prosecutrix. On the 13th of October I owed her 13l. 0s. 1d.; the prisoner came that day, and said."I want some money - my mother has a bill to pay for flour;" I gave him ten sovereigns, and he gave me this receipt - (reads.)
MRS. EDWARDS. He never returned to me after this; I have not had the money.

JAMES HENRY BRYNE
. I keep a chandler's-shop, and know the prosecutrix. I found the prisoner in Old-street; I took hold of him, and he said the money was all gone - I delivered him to an officer.

HENRY SHELDRAKE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found on him 17s. 4d.; he said that was all, but I found a bag with five sovereigns on him after that.
Prisoner's Defence. I think it useless to deny my guilt - I hope judgement will be passed with mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2189.
JOHN EDWARDS
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

CATHERINE EDWARDS
. I am a baker ; my husband left me eleven years ago - I do not know whether he is dead or alive. The prisoner is my son - he is twenty years of age; he was employed as my servant in business - I had a customer named
James Hook
, who owed me 1l. 3s. 4d.; the prisoner used to serve him - he accounted to me only for 13s. 4d. received from Mr. Hook, and said he had spent 10s. at skittles; he said it was a good thing he had saved that.

JOHN HOOK
. On the 17th of September the prisoner called on me, and I paid him 1l. 3s. 4d. on account of his mother.

WILLIAM HALL
. I took the prisoner; he was quite intoxicated - in taking him to the office he said he did not know what I took him for, unless it was disorderly conduct; I said it was for receiving 10s. - I said, "I don't wish to know any thing about it, but it is right you should know before you go before the Magistrate."
Prisoner's Defence (written).

On the 1st of last month I received warning to quit my mother's house, but owing to my not being able to get employment, she consented to let me stop until I could get into a situation. On the following Wednesday I went to the house of Mr. Hook with bread, who (without being asked), paid me 1l. 3s. 4d. as part of his bill; and on my leaving his house I met with some friends, and having no money of my own, I spent 10s., and of course gave my mother but 13s. 4d., she agreeing that she would stop it out of my week's wages; but on Monday she paid me my full money, telling me that she would place it to an account she had against me of monies paid by her on my account.

COURT to CATHERINE EDWARDS. Q. Why did you not charge him with this till October? A. Because I wanted to keep him in my house, but his conduct was such I could not endure it; I never gave him permission to take out money, but he has done it; I would have placed this to his account, but his conduct was such; he has put me in fear of my life - I have been forced to have an officer in the house to keep me from blows and insults - I did say I would place it to account that night, but my little son told me that he was just as usual, very drunk - I have devised every means to reclaim him.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Confined Six Weeks .

2190.
GEORGE BRISCALL
and
FREDERICK CRAWKSHAW
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 9 lbs. weight of beef, value 2s. , the goods of
John Day
.

JOHN DAY. I am a butcher , and live at Fulham
. On the 15th of October I was out; when I came home this beef was missing - I firmly believe it to have been mine.

JOHN TOUSE
. I am a gardener. On the 15th of October I saw Crawkshaw take a piece of beef from the prosecutor's shop-board, and put it into Briscall's apron.

ELISHA GIBBS
. I was going down a lane which leads to Shepherd's-bush; I saw the prisoners - one of them had a piece of beef in his apron; I ran up to them - they dropped the beef, and I pursued and took them; I showed the same beef to the prosecutor.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I took the prisoners, and found where the beef had been in their apron.

CRAWKSHAW'S Defence. When he heard the cry of Stop thief! he took Briscall, and said, "Throw it over the pales," but he would not - he then went on, but he ran and took him, when he heard there was 5s. reward offered.
ELISHA GIBBS. I knew of no reward at that time.

BRISCALL -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

CRAWKSHAW -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

2198.
ROBERT BUTLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16 of October , 1 fixture, (i.e.) 1 copper, value 10s., the goods of
Francis Whit
, and fixed to a certain building; 1 blanket, value 1s.; 1 apron, value 2d., and 1 knife, value 6d., the goods of
Hannah Roe
; 1 bonnet value 6d.; 1 piece of crape, value 2d.; 1 handkerchief value 2d.; 1 apron, value 2d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 6d., and 2 caps, value 6d. , the goods of
Jane Nash
.

HANNAH ROE. I had the care of a house at the corner of St. Martin's-lane
and Newport-street
; I left it on the 16th of October, at a quarter-past five o'clock in the evening; the property was then all safe - the prisoner was taken about half-past seven o'clock: I did not hear of it till the following morning, when I went to the house, and the things were gone; the blanket, apron, and knife belonged to me, and had been in the back parlour - there were some other articles of Jane Nash's; these are the articles - I know nothing of the prisoner.
JANE NASH. There were some things of mine in the house that evening, but I had not seen them for three weeks or a month - these are them.

GEORGE BOWER
. I saw the prisoner on the 16th of October, with a copper on his head, in Gray's Inn-lane - I asked where he got it; he said from No. 12, Tottenham-street - I was not satisfied, and left him with my brother officer; I went to the place he stated, and found it was not true; my brother officer found the other things on him; I fitted the copper in the house - it fitted exactly.

GEORGE FOSTER
. I was with Bower. I found these other articles on the prisoner, four picklock-keys, a phosphorus-box, and a screw-driver - they were all in his pockets.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am porter to Mr. Way - he is a grocer. I open and shut the house in question; I went on the morning of the 16th of October, and found the door half open; I went in and found no one - I went and told Mrs. Roe - we went in, and missed the articles.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a person in Rupert-street, who asked me to carry this copper over the water for him- the other things he said he brought from a lodging in Tottenham-street; I do not know the number - I thought it was 12.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

2192.
SAMUEL GILLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of September , 1 pair of trousers, value 12s. , the goods of
William Grimes
.
WILLIAM GRIMES. I am a shoemaker . I lost a pairof trousers on the 30th of September; I sent my son to the pawnbroker's for them.

WILLIAM GRIMES, JUN.
I was sent to take these trousers out of pawn; I was taking them home, and sat down on a step, to take a stone out of my shoe; the trousers were behind me - my brother was bargaining with a boy to change some apples for a knife; the boy went away, and my brother ran after him; I went after my brother, and left the trousers - when I came back they were gone.

JOHN BEE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in the City-road; I asked him about the trousers - he said they were at his mother's, and she had got them safe; I went there, and found them.
NOT GUILTY .

2193.
JAMES PRITCHARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 8lbs. weight of horse-hair, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Cole
.

THOMAS COLE. On the 15th of September I sent the prisoner to Mr. Martin, a dyer, with 63 lbs. of horse-hair; he did not come back till the Tuesday evening - I told him he had used me ill, and I should discharge him; he said he hoped I would forgive him - I said I could not; I went and inquired if the bag had been delivered at the dye-house; they said it had - I went for it on the Thursday, and they delivered it to me; I thought it was not all right - I had it weighed, and there were but 55lbs.

WILLIAM MARTIN
. The prisoner brought me a bag of cow-tail hair on the 15th of September; I did not weigh it- my servant took it in.

GEORGE MARTIN
. I am the son of William Martin. - I saw my father take the bag into the dye-house.
NOT GUILTY .

2194.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October , 3 knives, value 1s.; 3 forks, value 1s., and 1 tumbler-glass, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Wilkinson
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined Two Months .

2195.
MARIA WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of October , 4 table-cloths, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Millman
.

HENRY MILLMAN. I am a chop-house keeper , and live in Brydges-street
. On the 19th of October I lost four tablecloths from my dining-room - I was standing in front of my house, and a young man said to me "What business has this woman in the passage?" - I looked and saw the prisoner with the four cloths on her arm; I went to her, and she said I might take them, and let her go.

THOMAS MORTON
. I saw the prisoner on the staircase with the cloths on her arm - I went into the yard, and something struck me that all was not right; I turned back, and told the prosecutor.

JOHN EAMES
. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never had them in my hand - I merely walked in and out again; he pushed me out, and I said "Don't hurt me."
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

2196.
NICHOLAS SCOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October , 1 watch, value 3l.; 2 seals, value 2l.; 1 ring, value 10s., and 1 watch-key, value 10s, , the goods of
William Henry Taylor
.

WILLIAM HENRY TAYLOR. I lost a watch, seals, and a key, on the 20th of October, from the loft of the building of Mr.
Robert Taylor
's, in whose service I am - I left it safe in my chest, when I went on the top of the building for about an hour, and when I returned, it was gone - the prisoner was in Mr. Taylor's employ.
Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. How long has he worked in Mr. Taylor's employ? A. About three years, and had a very good character - he had 10s. or 12s. a week.

HERBERT JOHN CLARK
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Wardour-street - this watch was pawned with me on Monday, the 20th of October, between one and three o'clock, by the prisoner, in the name of William Scott; I am confident it was him, because he came a second time the same day, after we had closed business; and said he had lost the duplicate of the watch, and wished me to detain it, if it were brought to me - I would say nothing that night; the next day the prosecutor came and said he had received a letter, saying it was pawned at our house.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the value of it? A. It is worth altogether about 7l.; I lent him 2s. 6d., which was all he asked - had he asked more, it would have aroused my suspicions; I cannot fix the time more accurately than between one and three o'clock - I was in the shop all day, and may have had two hundred customers; but this was a remarkable case, it being pawned for 2s. 6d. it excited my attention.

Q. Can you call to mind your recollection of his features? A. His asking 2s. 6d. lulled my suspicion; I have said excited my attention - he came the second time between eight and nine o'clock in the evening; I have always named that hour, and never said it was between nine and ten - Mr. Harrison, my master, said that; I heard the prisoner say at the office he would account for where he was between nine and ten o'clock; nobody said "Then we must provide for that, or any thing like it;" I said it was between eight and nine - I went to Taylor and Beaumont's factory to point him out; he was the third man who came out, I recognized him by his countenance and dress - he had a blue coat and corderoy trowsers; there were ten or fifteen men - he came into the box when he pawned it, and I saw him as he went out at the door; I have not advised him to plead guilty - he was advised, but said he was not guilty, that he never saw me nor the watch; when he came at night, he came to the private door, and there was a very strong light over the door.
Q. Was Mr. Harrison present when the prisoner came a second time? A. No; I saw his brother at the office, and he is here - I have no doubt of the prisoner being the person.
MR. MILLER called -

HENRY GREEN
. I am a harness-maker, and work at Messrs. Taylor and Beaumont's factory. I know the prisoner, and recollect his being at the shop on Monday week; he was in the shop till one o'clock, when he went to dinner - he dines in Red Lion-street, Old Cavendish-street; the shop is in Brook-street, Bond-street - I saw himthere again when I returned, at five minutes before two - I do not know the precise time he returned; he complained of his head aching that afternoon - he staid till five o'clock and went to tea; I returned at half-past five, and found him in the shop then - he worked till eight o'clock - we went together across the square to Regent-street, and then down Oxford-street to the Middlesex-hospital; he turned to Tottenham-court-road, and I wished him good night; that was his road home - he lives with his father in Camden-town; it would take him about twenty minutes to go to his father's - he is very steady in his habits; I never was in the loft the watch was taken from; I know nothing of its being taken - I was not present when my master urged the prisoner to acknowledge having taken it; several of our men wear blue coats and corderoy trousers - I know nothing about an anonymous letter.

- SUPTON. The prisoner works under me at the shop; I recollect his being there on Monday week - he left at one o'clock, and told me he returned at half-past - I saw him again three minutes before two; I did not see him asleep - he is an honest hard-working lad; the loft the watch was in, is an open loft - trades-people pass through it.

ROBERT SHORT
. I work in the same shop; I recollect seeing the prisoner on Monday week; he returned from dinner at twenty-five minutes past one o'clock - he goes to Old Cavendish-street with his father to dine, as it is too far to go to Camden-town; I should think it would take him half an hour to go to Cavendish-street, eat his dinner, and return; I think I may venture to say he could not have gone to Wardour-street and eaten his dinner and returned; I heard no offer made to him about this.

COURT. Q. What day was it that he returned at twenty-five minutes past one o'clock? A. Last Monday week; it is my duty to attend the front-shop while the men go to dinner, to watch when they return - I have my dinner at two o'clock; two other men came between one and two - they were Green and Burn; Green came first of these two - there was no particular reason why I should notice the time the prisoner returned; but he generally does come about that time - he never takes his full hour, not one time in ten.

- SCOTT . I am the prisoner's father, and work for the same master, but not in the same factory. On Monday week I recollect his dining with me and my other son; we all dine together regularly - it takes us about twenty minutes to dine; I did not notice the time he left that day, but I think it wanted about five minutes of the half hour when he went away - he, being the youngest, generally puts away the dinner things; I recollect his being at home to tea at half-past five o'clock; and at night I went home a quarter-past nine, and he was at home before me - my wife said he had been in bed with a head-ache half an hour; I will take an oath he did not go out after I went home - he could not without my knowing it; I heard of the circumstance, and I said to him, "If you go to the pawnbroker and he swears to you, you know you will be prosecuted; but if you are guilty you have no occasion to go, the master won't prosecute you" - he said, "No, I am not guilty; I would sooner do any thing than confess a thing I am not guilty of."

JOHN SCOTT
. I am the prisoner's brother. I recollect his dining with me and my father that day - he went away about the usual time; no sooner than usual - when I went home at night he was in bed.

MARY ANN SCOTT
. I was at home at my father's on Monday week. The prisoner came home about twenty minutes to nine o'clock - he went to bed with a very bad head-ache, he had no supper - he continued in bed till my father came home; I suppose my father's house is half an hour's walk from Wardour-street.
- SUPTON . I remember his having a bad headache that afternoon; when he returned he could not do his work - I finished it for him.

MR. BEAUMONT . I am one of the proprietors of the factory. The prisoner has worked there four years - he is very sober, honest, and industrious; the pawnbroker came and picked him out - I pointed out the consequences to him, and told him if he were guilty to own it, and Mr. Taylor would not prosecute him, and we would employ him still; he said he was innocent.
NOT GUILTY .

2197.
JAMES WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of October , 1 coat, value 40s. , the goods of
William Wiggins
.
